text: I am so rusty on video :flushed: <@URAV154AV> helped me out yesterday pointing me to a good tool for quick edits. I'm wondering now on SEO best practices. Do people still publish the written transcripts on YouTube? or is that something we quit doing like 5 years ago?

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

elements.text: I am so rusty on video

helped me out yesterday pointing me to a good tool for quick edits. I'm wondering now on SEO best practices. Do people still publish the written transcripts on YouTube? or is that something we quit doing like 5 years ago?

text:
we do add a lot of text to add context but not the whole transcription! my intuition is that might be too boring for someone to actually read, lol.

we also link out to the blog that we have that's most closely related to the topic so that we can get clicks from that as well.

(here's a video for context: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jViFG47H9Ms>)

honestly this blog post on the topic is also quite good if you haven't already seen it  <https://backlinko.com/how-to-rank-youtube-videos>

attachments.title: 100 Ultra Effective Fundraising Ideas
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: 100 Ultra Effective Fundraising Ideas
attachments.video_html: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jViFG47H9Ms?feature=oembed&autoplay=1&iv_load_policy=3" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

attachments.title: YouTube SEO: How to Rank YouTube Videos in 2020
attachments.text: Wondering how to rank videos in YouTube and Google? In this post I show you my step-by-step YouTube SEO plan.
attachments.fallback: Backlinko: YouTube SEO: How to Rank YouTube Videos in 2020

text: New here so not sure where to ask this, but it's a question so this seems like a good place. How do you track conversions from content? ie blog to actual sign ups Google Analytics direct conversions? Assisted conversions? My boss wants to focus on more direct ROI and while I'm not opposed, I'm leery that those numbers only capture a small part of the value that our content creates (people interact with a brand 12 times before purchasing and all that), but maybe that's just the idealistic content creator in me :sweat_smile:  Are there other tools or metrics out there that you've found helpful in making the business case for content?

elements.text: New here so not sure where to ask this, but it's a question so this seems like a good place. How do you track conversions from content? ie blog to actual sign ups Google Analytics direct conversions? Assisted conversions? My boss wants to focus on more direct ROI and while I'm not opposed, I'm leery that those numbers only capture a small part of the value that our content creates (people interact with a brand 12 times before purchasing and all that), but maybe that's just the idealistic content creator in me
Are there other tools or metrics out there that you've found helpful in making the business case for content?

text: What is the thing that results in money changing hands? They pay for software? Buy a ticket to something?

elements.text: What is the thing that results in money changing hands? They pay for software? Buy a ticket to something?

text: Product signups. We have GA goals set up for both "click Get Started" and when they actually pay to upgrade.

elements.text: Product signups. We have GA goals set up for both "click Get Started" and when they actually pay to upgrade.

text: If you already have the goals set up on GA you can use Datastudio to track the blog posts' performance. In my team, we track how many leads, sign ups, mqls and customers our blog posts have brought us and we're constantly optimizing them when their conversion rates are too low. The thing is, we report on "first touch point", which basically means that the KPIs we measure are of people that were acquired from a form inside one of our blog posts (we have tons of lead magnets). I'm not too sure how I'd do it if I had to do a multi-channel approach

The thing is, we report on "first touch point", which basically means that the KPIs we measure are of people that were acquired from a form inside one of our blog posts (we have tons of lead magnets). I'm not too sure how I'd do it if I had to do a multi-channel approach

text:
The reason I ask, there is perhaps another way to look at it: push your boss to articulate when the “handoff” occurs between your team and the sales team. (This depends on the size of your company) But in some roles the content team gets traffic and that’s it. In others, they get emails. It’s hard for you to be measured on things you can’t control (i.e. whether the sales team is closing, whether the landing page is optimized, whether the product is keeping pace with customer expectations, etc) I suggest advocating you have a metric you are 100% in control of.

And if you are in control of all parts of the funnel to sign up, then the answer is probably a technical one (like <@UUH28N3U2>’s answer describes)

’s answer describes)

text: we use a product to track attribution in salesforce so we can see where / how people have engaged with content across books, blogs, newsletters etc throughout their buying journey

elements.text: we use a product to track attribution in salesforce so we can see where / how people have engaged with content across books, blogs, newsletters etc throughout their buying journey

text: I'd also add (days later...) that if the post was a revenue generating one, how much revenue was coming from it, and if there were specific links within the post that were being clicked to generate that revenue (you'd need to turn on events tracking for GA for this).

elements.text: I'd also add (days later...) that if the post was a revenue generating one, how much revenue was coming from it, and if there were specific links within the post that were being clicked to generate that revenue (you'd need to turn on events tracking for GA for this).

text: Hey, does anyone have experience hosting digital conferences/events? We’ve been hosting live events (which we love) but with all the travel banning in orgs. (we’re B2B) we’re really worried about attendance and have been considering making the learning events digital. We’ve seen it done well and poorly, and are just getting into preliminary research. For context, we’re quite comfortable with webinars and such, but have never attempted anything of scale. Any advice/tools/tech/experiences would be lovely!

elements.text: Hey, does anyone have experience hosting digital conferences/events? We’ve been hosting live events (which we love) but with all the travel banning in orgs. (we’re B2B) we’re really worried about attendance and have been considering making the learning events digital. We’ve seen it done well and poorly, and are just getting into preliminary research. For context, we’re quite comfortable with webinars and such, but have never attempted anything of scale. Any advice/tools/tech/experiences would be lovely!

text: +1 to this

elements.text: +1 to this

text:
we co-hosted one with Zoho. (they were the primary drivers of the event; it used their tech.)

it's _really_ hard to make it seem like something more than "a bunch of back-to-back webinars."

logistically, it required a lot more prep work to help the presenters get ready---lots of people using a platform that was new to them with different types of media in their presentations and varying quality of cameras/mics/etc.

there were plenty of things we didn't plan for. for example:

• when one presenter ran over, we were trying to ping the next one to hold on before they tried to takeover the screen, etc., etc.
• it was difficult to plan speaking times across timezones (attendees from India to U.S. West Coast); presenters in the UK, for example, wanted to be on when the European audience was likely to be watching.
the only real benefit (imho) was that it was easy to get presenters to sign on: their commitment was all of 30 minutes, and we could promise them access to an audience of several hundred attendees.

when one presenter ran over, we were trying to ping the next one to hold on before they tried to takeover the screen, etc., etc.

it was difficult to plan speaking times across timezones (attendees from India to U.S. West Coast); presenters in the UK, for example, wanted to be on when the European audience was likely to be watching.
the only real benefit (imho) was that it was easy to get presenters to sign on: their commitment was all of 30 minutes, and we could promise them access to an audience of several hundred attendees.

text: <@UJE5LQ2JC> -- Oi, this sounds familiar. For a while I was reporting on an open funnel of users who viewed blog content before product pages. Our theory at the time was that we were responsible for getting them in the door, but it was up to the product marketing folks to convert.

elements.text: -- Oi, this sounds familiar. For a while I was reporting on an open funnel of users who viewed blog content before product pages. Our theory at the time was that we were responsible for getting them in the door, but it was up to the product marketing folks to convert.

text: That + growing our email subscriber list, then driving conversions off of that. Newsletters were always strong performers.

elements.text: That + growing our email subscriber list, then driving conversions off of that. Newsletters were always strong performers.

text:
Hi Kyla! My company (B2B also) just hosted a virtual summit last week for around 1700 registrants (550ish who attended live). It was twelve 45 min sessions back to back, with a panel  and a q&a session to break up the day. Even though it is essentially a bunch of webinars in a row, feedback from the event was great. Ppl liked the virtual format and quite a few ppl tuned in for the full 11 hours which surprised me. 

As others have said, speaker coordination & logistics were definitely the main challenges. Just getting everyone familiar with the platform, ready to go at the right time, and troubleshooting various issues with the platform we used (Crowdcast). Honestly I was really frustrated by Crowdcast's technical issues in the lead up to the event, but I have to say it came through for us on the day and seemed to provide a good experience for attendees. Happy to answer any questions if I can be of assistance! :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:

Ppl liked the virtual format and quite a few ppl tuned in for the full 11 hours which surprised me. 

As others have said, speaker coordination & logistics were definitely the main challenges. Just getting everyone familiar with the platform, ready to go at the right time, and troubleshooting various issues with the platform we used (Crowdcast). Happy to answer any questions if I can be of assistance!

text: When it comes to homework assignments for job candidates, do you have examples that have worked for you or any you’ve taken that were valuable?

elements.text: When it comes to homework assignments for job candidates, do you have examples that have worked for you or any you’ve taken that were valuable?

text: <@UUH2HEXS6> can you share some of the materials you used to promote it? I'm mostly interested in how you framed/branded it? Did you call it a "virtual conference" "online experience? something else?

elements.text: can you share some of the materials you used to promote it? I'm mostly interested in how you framed/branded it? Did you call it a "virtual conference" "online experience? something else?

text:
One question I love asking as part of a take-home is to “tell us about a piece of content that you’re proud of and why” and then expressly explain that it’s ideal to show off the qualities & experiences mentioned in the job posting. This doesn’t take a ton of time on either side’s part and I find it very telling.

The best answers will tell a story and go behind the scenes, explain the strategy and/or impact of the piece, how the person worked with others, etc. It also provides a work sample of how this person would communicate in writing/async with our team & what their personal writing style is.

elements.text:

text: I can't find a copy of it now, but we had an editing test that was about 1.5 pages long that was great. We tried to make the issues as objective as possible: One paragraph was too wordy, one was entirely in passive voice, and there were a few misspelled names and figures that should have stood out as blatantly wrong and in need of checking. I think we did it as an on-site assignment, so maybe not what you're looking for, but we edit a lot of each other's work so having that skill test was really important to us!

text:
Hey <@UUKNHRX41>. We use Segment to send our GA data to Mixpanel. This gives us all the touch points a user takes before sign up along with their product activity in one place. We then use a mix of filters + segmentation + funnel + flow analysis to see if people who read our content converted.

Not sure what stack you use, but I hope this gives you an idea. Happy to answer any Qs. :)

elements.text: Hey

. We use Segment to send our GA data to Mixpanel. This gives us all the touch points a user takes before sign up along with their product activity in one place. We then use a mix of filters + segmentation + funnel + flow analysis to see if people who read our content converted.
Not sure what stack you use, but I hope this gives you an idea. Happy to answer any Qs. :)

text:
I thought the exercise for my current role was well-designed, though admittedly laborious. It was two-part:

The *first part* gave a copy of a recent customer interview, and asked me to map out a content campaign based on the insights and content of the interview, and then complete some small pieces of the campaign (examples included a promo email, short blog post, webinar run of show, video script, etc.)

The *second part* was a recent content audit with some high-level performance numbers, and I was asked to create a framework to gauge performance and identify areas of improvement.

The
second part
was a recent content audit with some high-level performance numbers, and I was asked to create a framework to gauge performance and identify areas of improvement.

text:
I did this exercise when I applied for a role at Hotjar. As the candidate, I was left with a sour taste in my mouth after they asked for so much and didn't provide any feedback whatsoever. My advice, as a candidate, is to provide great feedback - otherwise that person you didn't hire this time isn't going to want to be hired next time.

(I wrote a blog, made a video, and reviewed their website).
